item.title: Karise add a quote by Bernard M. Baruch
item.description: "Be who you are and say what you feel, because those who mind don't matter, and those who matter don't mind." -- Bernard M. Baruch

item.title: Karise add a quote by Marcus Tullius Cicero
item.description: "A room without books is like a body without a soul." -- Marcus Tullius Cicero

item.title: Karise add a quote by Frank Zappa
item.description: "So many books, so little time." -- Frank Zappa

item.title: Karise add a quote by Mark Twain
item.description: "If you tell the truth, you don't have to remember anything." -- Mark Twain

item.title: Karise add a quote by Martin Luther King Jr.
item.description: "Darkness cannot drive out darkness: only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate: only love can do that." -- Martin Luther King Jr.

item.title: Karise add a quote by J.R.R. Tolkien
item.description:
"All that is gold does not glitter, Not all those who wander are lost; The old that is strong does not wither, Deep roots are not reached by the frost.
From the ashes a fire shall be woken, A light from the shadows shall spring; Renewed shall be blade that was broken, The crownless again shall be king." -- J.R.R. Tolkien

item.title: Karise add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "I am enough of an artist to draw freely upon my imagination. Imagination is more important than knowledge. Knowledge is limited. Imagination encircles the world." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Karise add a quote by George Mac Donald
item.description: "Work is not always required. There is such a thing as sacred idleness." -- George Mac Donald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "Come, then, affliction, if my Father wills, and be my frowning friend. A friend that frowns is better than a smiling enemy. " -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "No story ever really ends, and I think I know why. " -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "A genuine work of art must mean many things; the truer its art, the more things it will mean. If my drawing, on the other hand, is so far from being a work of art that it needs THIS IS A HORSE written under it, what can it matter that neither you nor your child should know what it means? It is there not so much to convey a meaning as to wake a meaning. If it do not even wake an interest, throw it aside. A meaning may be there, but it is not for you. If, again, you do not know a horse when you see it, the name written under it will not serve you much. At all events, the business of the painter is not to teach zoology." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "There is this difference between the growth of some human beings and that of others: in the one case it is a continuous dying, in the other a continuous resurrection." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "To try to be brave is to be brave." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "Doing the will of God leaves me no time for disputing about His plans." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "All that is not God is death." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "Philosophy is really homesickness." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "I don't know how to thank you.' Then I will tell you. There is only one way I care for. Do better, and grow better, and be better." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "You thought you were going to be made into a decent little cottage: but He is building a palace. He intends to come and live in it himself. (Quoted by C.S.Lewis in Mere Christianity)" -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "I write, not for children,but for the child-like, whether they be of five, or fifty, or seventy-five." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "...it is so silly of people to fancy that old age means crookedness and witheredness and feebleness and sticks and spectacles and rheumatism and forgetfulness! It is so silly! Old age has nothing whatever to do with all that. The right old age means strength and beauty and mirth and courage and clear eyes and strong painless limbs." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "The boy should enclose and keep, as his life, the old child at the heart of him, and never let it go. He must still, to be a right man, be his mother's darling, and more, his father's pride, and more. The child is not meant to die, but to be forever fresh born." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "Once, as I passed by a cottage, there came out a lovely fairy child, with two wondrous toys, one in each hand. The one was the tube through which the fairy-gifted poet looks when he beholds the same thing everywhere; the other that through which he looks when he combines into new forms of loveliness those images of beauty which his own choice has gathered from all regions wherein he has travelled. Round the child’s head was an aureole of emanating rays. As I looked at him in wonder and delight, round crept from behind me the something dark, and the child stood in my shadow. Straightway he was a commonplace boy, with a rough broad-brimmed straw hat, through which brim the sun shone from behind. The toys he carried were a multiplying-glass and a kaleidoscope. I sighed and departed." -- George MacDonald

item.title: Karise add a quote by George MacDonald
item.description: "There is no slave but the creature that wills against its Creator." -- George MacDonald
